When I started playing Stoneshard, I regretted having sat on it for 5 years. Then I was happy that I had sat on it for 5 years. And then I realized that its biggest problem is that it has been in development for 5 years.

If you are intrigued by the game, and you want to discover it fully by itself, my cliff notes are: the most common complaints about it are really not that big of a deal, the game is delightful, and you will handily get more hours out of it than bucks you paid for, so for me it's a home-run of a recommendation, with the caveat that an otherwise addictive and super fun experience will arbitrarily nosedive around the halfway point in such a fascinating way that I feel compelled to expand upon it.

I've been mulling it over, and I think the best way to categorize this kind of game is to call it a "quicksand survival". Stoneshard, much like Qud or Outward, are games with survival elements on which the fact of [i]surviving[/i] requires little to no effort, just as if you were floating in quicksand: You will have no problem to keep up with food, hydration, shelter and basic upkeep, but any progress will require methodical and consistent effort, and any sudden moves will only make things worse.

The most common complaint about this game is that dying is extremely easy, and that doing so can set you back a table flippingly large amount of time. From the outset you will need to be very careful, as each skill tree will require a decent amount of investment to see returns on and an enemy getting a lucky hit is all it takes to go from a routine fight to staring at your monitor in disbelief knowing that you are going to die on the next move, and there's nothing you can do about it. When was the last time you slept by the way? Oh, 2 hours ago?

Ranged combat is something you will quickly learn to love in Stoneshard. Not only it will help you kite enemies and retain control of fights, but it also will secure a steady supply of money, food, and components for your character. In particular, pelts, which can be used to make bedrolls, which is how you save in this game, so, it's not about cramming all you'll need in a backpack, but if you're smart and patient, you can obtain, craft and utilize what's around you to make your game easier and more convenient, including more frequent saving.

The game wants to hammer into you that it wants you to play it safe, take your time and plan ahead, and once you understand this, it becomes a satisfying and addicting masterpiece. Gathering supplies, making preparations, taking contracts, heading back to town to cash them in and expanding your caravan, gaining levels and advancing skills will become a comfy and addictive loop that will keep you hooked for anywhere between 20 to 40 hours.

And then you will hit level 10. The best analogy I could put to hitting level 10 in Stoneshard is being softly stirred from the best dream ever by the steady tone of the emergency broadcast system.

You see, the game has a very strict tier system, meaning that, for all the variety in types of gear and weapons, you will unlock new gear types based on your character's level. In this case, level 10 means you will start seeing enemies with tier 3 gear, which is much better than the tier 2 stuff you have on you but is also much more expensive, which will, in turn, compel you to move to the next major area in search of more money, so you can keep up with the game's reactive difficulty. Makes sense, yeah?

The problem is that, while doing it, you will accumulate experience. This will increase your level. The next tier cutout is at level 15. Oh, look, you're already level 12. And just like that the realization will start creeping in that this game was not rewarding being patient and methodical, but that it wants you to budget a play time that, up to now, you had taken for granted. Leveling up goes from being excited at unlocking new skills and feeling powerful, to something to actively dread and avoid, because doing so will only mean making it more difficult and frustrating. Oh look, you're level 13!

It's not just the gear, though, as tier 3 enemies will come with their own set of skills. Suddenly keeping your distance and kiting will become increasingly difficult against groups of enemies that can dash half a screen and are immune to the crowd control you have been relying on up to now. Archery duels will consistently end with you on the losing side of an enemy that can dodge every shot while nailing every one of theirs thanks to increased stats and-- heeey, congratulations! You're level 14! Ah, don't worry, at least now you have enough to buy a full set of tier 4 armor right? What's that, you spent it all repairing the tier 3 armor that you thrashed fighting against them? Man, maybe you should go back and grind some money to-- [b]OH WOULD YOU LOOK AT THAT EXPERIENCE BAR GOING UP![/b]

Stoneshard is a game with impeccable foundations and a rock solid game loop whose extremely jagged progression is liable to leave you in an extremely unpleasant "fucked if you do fucked if you don't" situation through no fault of the player and even while playing in the game's own terms. I am still unsure how salvageable one such situation is, but I hope you understand how hopeless and unpleasant the game becomes once such a realization sinks in. This is probably the most egregious and by-design way the game can screw you over, but it is by no means the only one, as unfocused or even simply mistimed character progression can greatly hamper if not completely cripple your playthrough.

All of the above comes to mean there is only one viable (or at least, greatly preferred) way to go about Stoneshard: to metagame the fuck out of it. The developers themselves have stated that they expect someone to do multiple runs of the game, and, at first blush, it does not seem like a terrible idea, since missions will be different, POIs will be on different spots, and certain special events may cause you to adjust your playstyle, but the story will be the same, major locations will be in the same place, the steps will be the same, hell, character progression will be the same, at least if you know what's good for you. You'll fight the same enemies the same way, only more optimized and stringent, closer to the very specific answer that this given puzzle requires; none of the zippy, wacky and freeform progression of Qud, none of the (mostly) pressure free "try again" nature of Outward.

Stoneshard will punish you if you go too quick, and will punish you if you go too slow, in such a way that the amount of challenge is no longer decided by how hard the player wants to push, but imposed in such a jarring way that you can't help but wonder if it is just a product of being in Early Access for 5 years and the developers trying to develop a game for the people who have been that long playing it instead of considering that someone might not want to basically play the same game several times until they play it "right".

Stoneshard is one of those games that grabs you by the cloak and drags you straight into its grim, medieval misery—in the best way possible. The atmosphere is fantastic, the combat feels weighty, and every step into the wilderness has that “I really shouldn’t be out here but here I am” energy. The world is dangerous, enemies are rude, and the loot is… well, mostly onions and the like and broken to bits items, but somehow it’s still fun.

But despite all that charm, the game still feels like a beautifully constructed wagon missing a few wheels. Progression is thin, content runs out quicker than you expect, and we’re still waiting on things like proper character creation, which has been requested for so long it might as well qualify for veteran status. I'm bored of playing Mahir for the sixth time and I just want to design my own soon-to-be-mangled adventurer—is that too much to ask?

Saving is also an adventure of its own. Want to stop playing? Easy—just walk back to town, find a bed, and pray nothing eats you on the way (I know there's a bedroll or camps, this is a hyperbole). The RNG doesn’t help either; every fight feels like rolling dice with a trickster god. One moment you’re a tactical genius, the next your sword misses three times in a row and you get mauled by a small ghoul (jk I never got mauled by a small ghoul, but you get the gist of it). It keeps things interesting… in the same way that juggling chainsaws keeps things interesting.

Still, Stoneshard’s potential is undeniable. It’s fun, it’s atmospheric, and it feels so close to becoming something truly special. I’m really looking forward to the next update—hopefully soon—and hoping it brings enough new content that I can stop harvesting XP from woodland critters.

Personal scores:

Atmosphere: 9/10 (grim, immersive, and delightfully miserable)

Gameplay: 7/10 (fun but held hostage by RNG chaos)

Progression: 4/10 (needs expansion and polish)

Content: 5/10 (solid foundation, but the world still feels half-built)

QoL / Saving System: 3/10 (please… just let me save my game or make bedrolls smaller because why is it so big in my inventory)

Overall: 6.5/10 – A rough but lovable gem with serious potential. Looking forward to what’s next.

Had it on my radar for a long time. "Mostly positive" reviews... but why so many of them, I thought. Finally decided to try it, and oh boy.

Here my brief summary:

1. If you love difficulty, high stakes, resource management, strategic combat, good writing, a world that feels authentic and alive - this is a game for you.
2. If, on the other hand, you want to feel like an unstoppable deity, slaughtering thousands with every swing of your hand, you might be better off playing something else.
3. The game is far from being finished, but I definitely got my money's worth already. Kudos to the developers.
4. Special shoutout to whoever is doing the writing part. The quality of world presentation is top notch - this is how you bloody do it. No exposition devices, just little pieces of information here and there, slowly forming the big picture.
5. I'm generally somewhat indifferent to pixel art, but I love it when it goes the non-goofy, realistic way.
6. The aforementioned high-stakes part is no joke. I mean you can get killed even on the way back from a dungeon, quite easily in fact if you make a few wrong steps, loosing you a good chunk of time. But for me personally this is not frustrating - it just just adds to excitement. 
7. Playstyle variety is great. So far I went pure electromancer and I'm loving it, but I can see so many viable and completely different options available that I'm already planning my next playthrough even though I'm far from completing the current one.

All in all, a great catch for me. My heartfelt thanks to the developers.

A Masterclass in Harsh, Rewarding RPG Design

Stoneshard is one of those rare games that doesn’t just ask for your attention—it demands your respect. Every step, every decision, every bandage you don’t pack can shape the outcome of your adventure. And that’s exactly what makes it so unforgettable.

At its core, Stoneshard is a deep, turn-based tactical RPG with an atmosphere so thick you can practically smell the damp forests and dusty dungeon corridors. The game’s world feels brutal but fair; it never lies to you. If you die, it’s because you misjudged a fight, overextended, or didn’t prepare. And when you survive? It’s incredibly satisfying.

The progression system is one of its strongest points: entirely open-ended character building, tons of viable playstyles, meaningful gear choices, and a sense that your character is becoming stronger because you are getting better at reading situations and planning ahead.

The procedural content keeps things fresh, and the sound design—especially the ambient tracks and enemy cues—adds a surprising amount of tension. Even the little things, like lighting a campfire in the wilderness or inspecting your injuries after a narrow escape, make the experience immersive in a very grounded way.

Is it tough? Absolutely. But it’s the good kind of tough, the kind where every victory feels earned. If you enjoy games like classic roguelikes, tactical RPGs, or survival-heavy adventures, Stoneshard is easily one of the most rewarding games you can sink time into.

Verdict: A brutally honest, brilliantly crafted RPG that rewards thought, patience, and creativity. Highly recommended.

Reduce the cost and inventory size of the bedroll, make it multi-use or once per day. Or let it last 5-10 days, not one time use, so that you can lay it down at a dungeon entrance to free up space before going in and it will be there when you escape for a save and heal up. Or campfire allows rest (save but not sleep) and reduces ambush. Combine campfire + bedroll for best camping.

A great game — but it leaves you with more questions than answers.
Is it really possible to make a “perpetual motion” game — something that keeps making money for decades with almost no effort? Apparently yes. With AA-level sales, they’re still releasing content on the level of “added two new upgrade branches in a 2D game.”
Some might say, “They need to fix the balance!” — except there is no balance to fix, and anyone who played enough will tell you that. And with hundreds of thousands of sales, why is there still no proper campaign, just 5–6 short missions?
Seems like the devs — with rather questionable morals — accidentally made a brilliant foundation, then blew all the money in a casino. Now there are two and a half programmers left, adding tiny updates for a bowl of soup, just to make it look like the project isn’t dead and to keep Steam from flagging it as abandoned.
You’ll have fun, no doubt about that. But even six years later, it’s still an unfinished mess that will never be completed. Updates will stop the moment people forget about it. Don’t expect this one to ever be finished.

Another "I really want to like this game BUUUT" review, because that's just how it is - I played this game 4+ years ago for the first time, got into it a bit and then put it aside. Now I came back after all these updates and my opinion just hasn't changed much.

There's a lot to love - The game's overall style & artwork, the atmosphere, all the survival elements, the RPG character building, the fairly massive world with a crap ton of things to do .... but the gameplay just has some issues I can't get past.

My biggest gripe: this game describes itself as a hardcore RPG, but SO much of it is tied to sheer chance & RNG and not actual skill and knowledge. Crits, Dodges, Blocks, status effects, general bodypart damage - pretty much everything surrounding combat is based on chances and (frankly too many) miniscule modifiers. The game starts throwing dungeons with like 30+ enemies at you at just character level 7 with pretty much every room housing 3-5 enemies at a time. If you die in one of the last rooms after going through it very carefully for like an hour due to missing/fumbling multiple skills in a row, getting caught in a net and obliterated by a single enemy you beat before without much trouble... ALL of that was pure bad luck. Dying rarely feels like it was actually YOUR fault as the player because you did something wrong, but rather bc the game didn't give you a chance that time. There are barely any things you can do in the first place to change the pace of a fight - with a single character you usually develop a sort of go-to way of fighting and you just repeat that over and over again. Having to just replay these 1-2 hrs over and over until you get lucky is NOT fun or engaging gameplay. Kiting single enemies away from groups EVERY TIME (because you pretty much always fight 1v3+ at some point) which also doesn't quite work reliably anyway is NOT fun either.

All that would be doable if you weren't alone and tied to a single character build. Something like NPC companions that could fill other roles of a RPG group to actually give you more strategic and tactical options as a player would be extremely nice, but... I don't think we'll ever get that.

The way the game plays now, you have to spend a LOT of hrs grinding out your character with procedurally generated quests to handle the RNG a bit easier and have some more skills and options during a fight. The game just seems to love wasting your time instead of giving you more tactical depth through other means. If we're talking "hardcore RPGs" - let's compare it to something like Fear & Hunger II Termina. A game that actually runs on the players knowledge & skill and gets progressively easier and easier the more you understand about the game and how it wants to be played. The sheer number focus of Stoneshard completely goes against that. Your skill barely matters. I don't even hate the save system by itself, it's the reasons why you die that makes it not work well here.

I wish I could get into this game because there's so much work that was put into it over the years... but I just get incredibly frustrated by how much this game requires you as the player to "make it more fun" by grinding the heck out of it instead of engaging with it in a more meaningful way. I can see how a character at like level 25+ could be fun to play as... but how long would it take to get there and would that have been worth it?

I really want to like this game and I’m basically the ideal target audience for it. But I just can’t get comfortable with the permadeath/save-on-sleep system. I don’t mind losing progress in general, I’ve played plenty of roguelikes with permadeath, but here it just feels frustrating. Every time you die, you have to pick up the same quests again, talk to the same people, explore and loot the same locations, prepare and so on. It’s simply boring after the 3rd time.

If you don’t play with permadeath and stick to the default save-on-sleep mode, the issue is less severe, but you still have to travel back to the place where you died (and travel times can be ridiculously long) and redo the same dungeon, which gets boring fast, too. On top of that, you need to spend a bit of time preparing and juggling your needs before heading to a dungeon, which makes the whole experience even more exhausting.

Caves of Qud suffers from a similar problem, but it’s way less prominent there. Regardless, in the end I abandoned it for the same reason. ToME has this a little bit too, but weirdly it never bothered me as much as it does in Stoneshard or CoQ.

In games like DCSS, Brogue or Dungeons of Dredmor, each run feels fresh and different and when you die and restart, you’re thrown straight back into the action without all the repetitive, tedious overhead you get in Stoneshard.

What also bugged me: The meat of this game is exploring dungeons and fighting (at least for me) and all the countless other systems the devs introduced are nice in theory and I'm not opposed to them per se, but IMO they overdone it. The constant juggling of all the mechanics (hunger, thirst, multiple factors affecting morale, fatigue, sanity, intoxication, injuries, pain, equipment repair, constant inventory management because it's so small etc.) just gets annoying after a while and keeps you from jumping into the fun parts of the game.

So, with a heavy heart, I’m going to set this game aside. It feels like it doesn’t respect my time and I hate that, especially since my time for gaming is very limited these days. IMO the design of Stoneshard doesn't pair well with its save system and certainly not with permadeath, which ended up being a dealbreaker for me.

P.S.: I can already hear the “sKiLl iSsUe” morons yelling.. but difficulty is not the point here, although many of the systems I listed are either poorly explained or not explained at all, which is a real problem for beginners. And yeah, sure, you can read up on them and figure out the best ways to manage all of this stuff efficiently (which I did btw.) but what matters, is that in the end it’s still just not fun and tedious. At least for me. I’d rather be crawling dungeons than spending half of my precious gaming time managing my character’s well-being, juggling my inventory and equipment or slogging through the boonies to the next dungeon during early game.

I really wanted to like this game. It has amazing music and wonderful atmosphere, but some of the mechanics are just infuriating.

The save system is punishing. In order to save the game, you have to spend money at an inn or invest in a sleeping bag. The sleeping bag is prohibitively expensive and takes up about 1/3 of your inventory space. So, if you go out from your save location to go to a mission, complete the mission, and then get killed by a wild dog, you get to start the whole ordeal again.

Combat is frustrating. The game advises you that you are not a hero and to try to break up enemy hordes into smaller groups to tackle them, or to use your environment to your advantage. There don't seem to be many practical ways of doing this, with gangs of mooks being able to swarm me easily. Retreat is not a feasible option 90% of the time - if you are adjacent, you being victim to attacks of opportunity, if you are not adjacent, they can still keep up with you at identical speed. Not to mention that many of the enemies seem to have a ranged weapon or a special ability that allows them to charge multiple tiles at once. If the save system was not so punishing, it would at least give me the opportunity to test some different tactics and strategies without having to walk hundreds of wilderness tiles each time.

The inventory system is the diablo style inventory system, except, unlike in Diablo, you also have to deeply worry about hauling a stash of medicine, food, and water with you. Many things take up more space than seems intuitive - picking up herbs in the field typically takes two slots and is not stackable for instance. It also needs some QOL updates, like being able to press the autosort while an item is held in the cursor to make it a little better,

There are many many mechanics in this game, and a lot of things sound interesting, but being unable to really get my foot in the door is preventing me from exploring any of these things further.

There are some pros to this if these things sound up your alley. I have not noticed any obvious bugs in the game and the developers are active. Many people seem to love this game, so maybe it is just me. There is a demo so you can try and see for yourself if this is something you will like.

It has its pros and cons like every other game ever but damn if the cons are the most baffling decisions ever, they cripple the experience to the point that it feels more like I'm dragging myself to a torture session. It really feels bad. For instance, some of the cool parts of the game are:

- The combat is kind of cool, with in deep mechanics and events (there's nothing more satisfying that hitting a critical, watching the enemy melt and their friends run for their lives).
- The amount of status effects and stats is really cool.
- The procedural nature of the game makes it dynamic and the dungeons feel fresh every time.
- The caravan is a great HUB.

But then, you get some of the weird decisions and issues like:

- The skill tree and the skill points of your character cannot be re-assigned EVER. So if you, by chance, were not a professional player at the start of the game, your character might be doomed to be soft-locked due to combat incompetency. (people solve this with Cheat Engine).
- The combat can be a drag: most of the combat can be resumed in "potion shoving". You tank, get absolutely wrecked then heal and repeat, it gets old really quick.
- [strike] The game doesn't allow you to get an in-game clock, but then will ask you to complete a quest in a period of time, some contracts that must be completed in a day. This is the definition of baffling design. [/strike] (read developer response).
- Difficulty is all over the place: tier 3 difficulty is 10 times harder than tier 2 difficulty, mostly due to the amount of enemies you have to fight.
- Difficulty, again: what's the deal with animals in this game, they're near impossible, a bear can kill in 2 hits (turns) and can tank 40 hits (turns) with tier 3 gear, so why the fuck is there a quest to haunt bears in the starting area?.
- The save system: is bad, i don't think I have to elaborate, It's just that bad, thank god you can "Scum Save" from the game files.
- [strike] The turn-based system makes no sense sometimes: enemies can easily cheat the system (you too and it makes no sense), you can get hit while running away from an enemy; for instance, you use a turn to move away - the enemy then moves near you AND hits you at the same time... What in the actual fuck?. [/strike] (RNG mechanic, read developer response).
- The loot feels meaningless and useless: you don't get much useful loot in the dungeons, almost nothing, everything must be bought from the towns, dungeons are there to get things you can sell and to complete contracts. This leads to player not feeling rewarded for their adventures.
- The community is the most unbearable bunch of wanna-be high effort, low IQ "git gud" souls-like scum that you can find out there, edgy guys with too much free time... (actually not all of them, some folks are actually helpful).

The developers want a "hard-core experience" which means: our game is full of inconveniences for the sake of it. Okay, make it the default difficulty, but at least give an option to make the game playable. I really want to like and play this game. I wouldn't have poured 30 (53 edit time) hours into it otherwise, but the developer doesn't want people to enjoy it, and no, it's not that the game it's "not made for you" is just that the game it's not made for anyone. Interesting game, with lots of neat crafting and itemization but for some odd reason the devs thought it would be a good idea to make the game punishingly hard in the beginning.  Literally every 2v1 is fatal.  And when you die you have to go back to your last save...Oh and it's EXTREMELY hard to save in this game...basically you can save in town or if you use a bedroll.  So you basically have to save outside of the dungeon area using a bedroll and if you make any mistake and die, you have to start over.  You really can't run away from anything like you can in games like Kenshi.  So any situation where you are overmatched = start over...and you're overmatched in most situations unless you can spot the enemies and avoid them before they see you.

I suppose there are masochistic gamers out there that have endless hours to spend retracking their progress over and over and over but I'm not one of them.  My 120 minutes of playtime was spent just replaying the tutorial, trying not to die and then venturing out of town a few times only to get killed by dogs or bandits and end up right back at the start of the game.

I know there is a trend among developers now where they are trying to differentiate themselves from all the boring theme park sandbox games out there by promising their games are "super challenging" and "unforgiving" but most of them fall short and are just repeating many of the mistakes Japanese developers made back in the 80's and 90's on the old Nintendo.

This game lures you in with its pretty Artistic Direction and immersion but don't get fooled by its cover, it's not a Strategy nor a Roguelike game (as tagged on Steam). 
It is turn-based but there is no tactical element, it's hit as much as you can and pray you don't get killed before your enemy(ies)
And yes, given it wants itself to be realistic, almost everything is as strong or stronger than you so you will die (many times) but simply because the game is punitive and unforgivable, not because you lack skill or are a tactical wiz. Strategy boils down to engaging an enemy correctly and praying they don't have a group hidden past your field of vision otherwise, it's certain death. The save system is just another gimmick to make the game even more repetitive and frustrating.

Not for people who only have a couple of hours a day to play and relax, this game is not that. It's a game where you're constrained on where and when you can save, die often due to bad luck, and have re-do and re-do and re-do and re-do and re-do the same contracts/quests until luck gets on your side.

A lot of it is pretty-looking and well implemented but not well-thought-out, most mechanics are just gimmicky constraints (standard of survival games) that add nothing to the survivalism or immersion of the game (think diet morale), most RPG elements are only to serve you the illusion of choice when in fact, they are clearly choices that are better than others: and therefore the choice is really do you really want to role play and increase the already hellish difficulty of the game or pick the few best character builds which make the game somewhat more bearable. And the roadmap is not going in the direction I would want the game to go (no pets, or companions, etc.). Will shelve it indefinitely after almost 20h, will dust it off in a year or two to see if it has REALLY improved.

As is (early-access), would not recommend.

What the game should have at launch:
- Pretty much all most used Mods should be part of base game (UI+, quicksaves, etc.)
- More tactical options, combat needs to be rethought completely (it's a purge at the moment and not enjoyable)
- Companions so it's not constantly a one-against-many battle
